chinese_paragraphs: 華府對於人工智慧的討論，已愈發聚焦於美國該如何在與中共間的人工智慧競賽中取勝。美國總統川普（Donald Trump）重返白宮後首要政策之一，就是簽署一紙行政命令，宣布有必要「維持並強化美國在全球人工智慧領域的優勢地位」。2025年2月巴黎人工智慧行動高峰會（AI Action Summit）中，美國副總統范斯（JD Vance）強調，政府將致力於確保讓「美國的人工智慧科技持續成為全球標竿」。同年5月，川普政府的人工智慧與加密貨幣「沙皇」塞克斯（David Sacks），以「贏得人工智慧競賽」的必要性為正當理由，將先進人工智慧晶片出口至阿拉伯聯合大公國與沙烏地阿拉伯。
(Source: Shutterstock)
2025年2月11日，巴黎人工智慧行動高峰會期間，美國副總統范斯上臺發表演說。(Source: 達志/AP)

鑑於人工智慧在未來數十年可能扭轉各國之實力與繁榮，與其落敗，不如贏得這場競賽。不過要決定誰才是王者，仍取決於勝利的定義為何。一種常見的定義是要成為跨越通用人工智慧（Artificial General Intelligence, AGI）門檻的第一人，簡單來說，通用人工智慧是一種人工智慧模型，其在多種認知任務領域中的表現與頂尖人類專家旗鼓相當。通用人工智慧能夠在科學、技術及經濟生產力等方面解鎖非凡突破—而第一個開發出通用人工智慧的國家，將可取得領先優勢。
不過通用人工智慧並非人工智慧競賽中的唯一主戰場。軍方與情報機構必須善用人工智慧的潛力促成變革，同時降低其帶來的負面影響。同樣地，如果國家能夠在經濟與社會層面大規模採用人工智慧，將在競爭中脫穎而出。各國政府亦爭相訂定並主導能支撐起全球技術生態系的業界標準、供應鏈及基礎設施。且所有國家都應避免在人工智慧安全上陷入惡性競爭—有時更應共同努力—以管控人工智慧因濫用或失控所帶來的安全風險。

若將這些額外的人工智慧競賽納入考量，美國所處地位顯得岌岌可危。雖然美國企業在人工智慧研發領域保持領先優勢—但差距正在縮小—華府仍可能在其他人工智慧競賽中落敗。中共擁有極大優勢，但這兩個超級大國似乎缺乏共同防患未然的意願。由於人工智慧具有改變世界的潛力，這場競賽的代價極為深遠：一旦失利將使美國陷入經濟依賴、軍事能力出現弱點，以及全球領導地位下降。此一黯淡的未來仍有可能避免。不過美國必須訂定出一套具體人工智慧戰略，在創新、整合及風險降低之間取得平衡，將國家巨大的技術動能轉化為持久的戰略優勢。
◎創新競賽

在人工智慧競爭中，通用人工智慧是最醒目，也是目前最激烈的戰場。美國的OpenAI、Anthropic及Google DeepMind與中國大陸的深度求索（DeepSeek）等私人企業，在各自政府的支持下，正加速推動創新。沒人確切知道科技將如何發展。大型語言模型可能是通用人工智慧誕生的初始預兆，又或者當人工智慧模型突破某個臨界點時，真正的通用人工智慧就會出現。不論如何，通用人工智慧的潛力足以改變國家權力與競爭力的源頭，因此，世界上兩個人工智慧大國都對確保先驅者優勢保持極大的關注。
美國的人工智慧實驗室目前占有明顯優勢，這得益於美國為維持對中國大陸運算能力優勢而實施的半導體出口管制。但此一領先態勢並不穩固。中國大陸透過國內創新、規避出口管制，以及竊取智慧財產權的行為，使其得以緊追美國之後並位居第二位。位於中國大陸的人工智慧公司，如深度求索，目前正開發的技術僅比美國同業落後幾個月。而北京政府所採取的集權式作法，可使其比美國華府更快速地培育、整合及有效運用私人企業之創新。
與此同時，美國的開源系統有助於促進創新，但在本質上很容易受到間諜滲透與演算法快速傳播的影響。在演算法設計或人工智慧發展的替代模式上出現突破，可能會削弱美國半導體領域的優勢地位，而這些技術的傳播，則可能使中國大陸的人工智慧實驗室超越美國。由於受到其他政治優先事項之影響，川普政府目前正縮減對人工智慧基礎研發的投資，並限制優秀外國人才在美國工作的機會，此舉有可能在未來幾年影響美國人工智慧的發展。

此外，美國的私人企業多以商業需求為導向，未必跟國家優先需求一致。例如，人工智慧企業的運算中心，通常設置於能源基礎設施穩固的地點—無論該地點是否位於美國。中東地區有利的監管環境與豐富資源，就受到了青睞。全球首座五百萬瓩（Five-Gigawatt）的人工智慧資料中心將建於阿拉伯聯合大公國，而非美國—源自於川普政府近期決定將數十萬片先進人工智慧晶片出口至阿布達比（Abu Dhabi）所致。此一安排確實能讓華府從中受益，包含OpenAI與微軟在內的美國公司，預計將運用該資料中心的大部分容量。但將重要基礎設施移至安全性有疑慮的海外地區，也可能為中共與其他競爭對手開啟後門，進而取得先進運算資源與人工智慧模型。
就算美國能在創新競賽中保持領先，這樣恐怕還不夠。目前的市場趨勢顯示，各種先進人工智慧模型正日益普及且差異性不大，以至於沒有任何一方能獲得明顯的技術優勢。若此趨勢在通用人工智慧興起時仍無改變，勝利將取決於誰能有效運用人工智慧—且無法保證美國能脫穎而出。
◎確保優勢
在國家安全領域裡，有效運用人工智慧須瞭解先進人工智慧所賦予的能力（以及潛在之威脅），並將人工智慧整合進現有架構，以確保軍事上的決定性優勢。人工智慧的整合可望提升情報處理能力，加速資料驅動的決策，優化後勤與資源配置，推動精密的自主系統，甚至有可能成功開發出「神奇武器」—例如能癱瘓對手重要基礎設施與指管系統的網路武器，或者用於防禦層面上，使國家免受網路攻擊之侵擾。

美國政府與私人企業亟需共同合作，以實現人工智慧之整合，但目前雙方的合作仍極其有限。國家安全機構缺乏及早取得最新人工智慧模型的管道，導致難以快速將最新科技融入其工作流程。尖端人工智慧實驗室、美國國防部及其他國家安全機構間之合作關係，仍處於初期階段。冗長的採購流程、抗拒改變的作業文化、基礎設施與數據的缺乏，以及對人工智慧潛力的誤解—無論是低估或高估其能力—都阻礙了美國政府充分善用矽谷創新成果的能力。儘管上述這些問題已廣為人知，但解決起來卻十分困難。

相對地，中共的極權體制利於軍民整合，具備人工智慧的實務運用結構性優勢。也就是說，一旦北京授權執行，民間最新技術就能迅速轉化為軍隊戰力與情報能力。目前，共軍已採用人工智慧，積極攜手企業與學界共同合作。中共透過人工智慧競賽與公共採購平臺，將民用人工智慧研究成果轉化為軍事應用，並計劃於2030年前運用「演算法作戰」與「網狀化作戰」。這不僅是將演算法運用於武器系統，更是一種新戰爭型態的轉變，軍事優勢將取決於演算法的速度、複雜度及可靠度。
在人工智慧的競賽中，美國的OpenAI與中國大陸的深度求索等私人企業，展開激烈的競爭。(Source: 達志/AP)

維持創新的先驅地位是必要的，但還不足以在國家安全領域的競賽中贏得勝利。美國可以接連不斷地創造科學與技術上的突破，卻猶未能察覺到人工智慧開啟了一條通往革命性軍事或情報能力的技術新途徑。華府的官僚體系旨在逐步改善現行體制，但這往往使人難以想像新興科技能夠帶來出乎意料的可能性。相比之下，北京政府的集權化決策體系能更迅速找出具有顛覆性的途徑並加以運用，可能導致美國雖占有技術上的優勢地位，卻在戰略上遜人一籌。
◎整合要務

人工智慧競賽的贏家，還須將人工智慧整合進國家經濟—確保人工智慧能廣泛普及，並擴展到教育、能源、金融、健康、物流及製造等各種產業。推動消費者與商業人工智慧應用的科技公司、熱衷資助創新的創投生態、相對較高的數位識讀能力，以及大量的數位基礎設施，都為美國帶來顯著優勢。但成功並非能手到擒來。如果各層級的企業與政府人士無法為人工智慧的整合創造良好誘因，並建立充分的公眾信任，私營部門恐難以快速運用人工智慧，從而錯失提高生產力與創造新價值的契機。人工智慧亦存在一種隱憂，其不只是增強勞動力，還會取而代之。Anthropic公司執行長阿莫戴（Dario Amodei）不久前提出警示，人工智慧可能會在五年內造成美國20%的失業率—此一情勢恐對經濟與美國社會造成嚴重衝擊。

與此同時，中共在人工智慧經濟運用的競賽中，有望展現出驚人表現。中國大陸的企業領袖更著重於人工智慧之應用，而不僅只是人工智慧模型的開發。例如，深度求索的開源模型，有助於降低所有中國大陸人工智慧模型的成本，讓更多企業能夠嘗試這項技術。這會給予中共優勢，創造出能扭轉局面的產品。此外，中共政府在人工智慧取代勞動力所造成的政治後果方面，承擔較低的風險。在華府，其對工作自動化感到擔憂，在北京，則可能將人工智慧之應用視為中共人口急速老化與勞動力短缺的解方。

即便美國像中共一樣積極在經濟各層面採用人工智慧，但若中共能更佳利用人工智慧來促使製造業進步，尤其是機器人領域，美國仍可能會輸掉整場競爭。中共在工業機器人裝置數量上領先全球：2024年，中國大陸製造商採購全球半數以上的工業機器人，且該國工廠的人機數量比超過全球均值。「黑燈工廠」逐漸普及，全面自動化變得愈發普遍，例如電子公司小米的智慧型手機工廠可全天候無人運作。隨著人工智慧在空間推理與「具身智能」領域上出現長足的進步—人工智慧使機器人能於實際環境進行互動並從中學習—工廠機器人將可執行更廣泛且複雜的實體工作。
美國公司雖然在軟體與服務上表現優異—這些領域若採用人工智慧亦可望大幅提高生產力—但近幾十年來，美國在諸如製造、物流、能源及基礎建設等實體產業方面已然落後於中共。中共憑藉國家主導的產業政策與龐大的製造業基礎，其可在這些領域中大規模運用人工智慧，達成驚人的生產力成長，最終超越美國經濟。
◎營造有利條件

全球科技巨頭現正爭相建設數位基礎設施，以便促進人工智慧的全球發展、部署及應用。雖然這主要是美「中」兩國間之競爭，但其他成熟的科技大國（如法國、日本、荷蘭、南韓、臺灣及英國）與雄心勃勃的新興國家（如巴西、印度、沙烏地阿拉伯及阿拉伯聯合大公國）亦紛紛加入戰局。每個參與國家都期望能掌握人工智慧所需的數據、晶片暨資料中心及基礎模型，並對全球人工智慧規範與標準施加影響力。正如人工智慧與加密貨幣「沙皇」賽克斯近期表示：「如果世界上有八成的國家使用美國的技術堆疊系統，代表美國在競賽中占上風。反之若有八成源自於中共，則意謂著美國失利。」
半導體晶片的出口管制為美國取得了顯著優勢。美國公司擁有管道取得運算能力所需的晶片，而世界上許多國家也都渴望獲得美國晶片，因為其品質最佳。川普政府正試圖運用此一優勢，從沙烏地阿拉伯與阿拉伯聯合大公國等夥伴國家為起點，以美國晶片與資料中心「大量占據該地區」。此一作法是為了確保市場力量投入巨資建立數位基礎設施的地區，能運用美國的技術。

但是在收入較低、客戶數較少及寬頻連線與電力等基礎建設較缺乏的國家，華府這套順應市場力量的戰略將導致投資不足。這正是非洲、拉丁美洲、中東、南亞及東南亞等許多國家的現狀，這些國家都想要藉助人工智慧來提振經濟成長。中共在這些地區具備超越美國的條件，透過提供較不先進但價格更低的人工智慧模型—並補助運行這些模型所需的實體與數位基礎設施。中共目前或許無法出口任何尖端晶片，但對於許多開發中國家而言，成本與普及更為重要，中共提供的產品至少「比下有餘」，仍可能具有莫大吸引力。

若美國讓出這些新興市場，可能會面臨這些未來風險：美國贏得尖端科技競賽，卻將全球人工智慧生態系的主導權拱手讓給中共。對華府來說，這樣的後果不僅限於失去地緣政治影響力與商業機會。中共的人工智慧模型與基礎設施經常包含數位極權的價值觀，讓北京政府得以透過此管道輸出國家管控的機制，並在境外塑造合乎其觀點的歷史與政治敘事。此類技術透過臉部與聲音辨識系統，以大量數據分析監控個人與標記「可疑」行為，進而達成其監控目的。這些模型會自動屏蔽任何批判中共或敏感議題的相關內容，如天安門事件、臺灣、香港、維吾爾族或中共領導人習近平。該演算法亦會編造與散布親「中」的宣傳言論。相較之下，美國的人工智慧模型更重視民主規範、透明度、隱私保障、使用者的選擇及數據保護架構，有助於降低政府濫用的機會。為了確保塑造出全球現代生活的科技符合民主價值，華府須主動給予誘因，鼓勵美國的人工智慧公司於開發中國家投資且建設基礎設施。

錯誤的政策選擇，可能會導致美國在建設與管理全球人工智慧基礎設施的競賽中失去優勢。過度嚴峻的出口管制，可能會疏遠盟友，甚至促使目前觀望中的國家轉而選擇中國大陸製的產品。相對而言，若對先進人工智慧晶片實施的管制過於鬆散，則可能不小心使中國大陸公司取得這些晶片或從遠端存取開了後門，從而加速中共的科技創新。若華府無法條理分明地對其科技治理說出一套令人信服的願景—既能兼顧國家安全、經濟開放及民主價值—那麼潛在的國際合作夥伴有可能投靠他國。中共不僅只販售人工智慧；更是用極具財務與政治吸引力的條件，對世界上大部分國家提供一套能快速現代化的綜合工具包。對於渴望運用人工智慧來獲取經濟利益與改善治理的開發中國家而言，中共提供的方案往往是最實用且最容易付諸實現的途徑。
◎惡性競爭？

即使美「中」兩國都想在人工智慧競賽中勝出，也不能忽視通用人工智慧與其他高效能人工智慧模型所帶來的潛在威脅。至關重要的是，任何一方都不能坐視人工智慧的快速發展與運用會造成災難發生的可能性增加。非國家行為者或流氓國家將人工智慧模型武器化，人工智慧導致軍事行動意外升級，又或是超級智慧（Superintelligence）系統失去控制，這些都會引爆災難性的後果。要避免這樣的局面，人工智慧大國在相互競賽的同時，絕不能在安全問題上便宜行事。

近期最迫切的災難性風險是，若非國家行為者取得先進人工智慧系統，則可能發動大規模網路攻擊癱瘓金融體系，或設計並釋放高破壞率與高傳播率的電腦病毒。這不再只是科幻小說情節。在人工智慧發展位於領先地位的公司指出，其公司內部對危險能力的定義—是以「提升」來衡量，即人工智慧模型顯著提升某惡意行為者的能力—而此一危險能力的閾值很有可能於2025年突破。另一項快速逼近的威脅，則是可能誕生與人類價值或宗旨背道而馳的超級智慧，因設計缺陷、模糊指令或無法預測情境等因素，而採取危害人類福祉的行為。有愈來愈多證據顯示，尖端人工智慧模型能夠展現出欺騙性或計謀性的行為，使得此一風險愈發讓人相信並非危言聳聽。
防止危險人工智慧能力的擴散與失控通用人工智慧的誕生，對於華府與北京政府而言皆有益處。此一共同立場為美「中」兩個人工智慧大國創造合作機會—即使兩國正處於激烈的科技競爭中—以便能更深入瞭解人工智慧濫用與出現偏差的風險，以及找出並發展有效的緩解措施。
對華府而言，無論其他人工智慧大國做些什麼，尋求減輕人工智慧威脅的方法—川普政府已正視此一當務之急—都會是明智的政策。即便失控人工智慧未導致全球性災害，但一樁源自美國的重大人工智慧相關事件，無論是意外或疏忽，都會打擊人們對美國科技的信心。再者，如果美國被視為無法控管人工智慧的無窮力量，其全球性的領導地位與道德權威將受到質疑，中共將能藉由承諾穩定與控制來填補由此導致的權力真空。
近期最迫切的災難性風險是，若非國家行為者取得先進人工智慧系統，則可能發動大規模網路攻擊癱瘓金融體系，或設計並釋放高破壞率與高傳播率的電腦病毒。(Source: shutterstock)
◎成功方程式
美「中」兩國間各種人工智慧競賽的發展軌跡緊密交織。例如，贏得通用人工智慧發展競賽，將能提振領先國家的國家安全、經濟活力及全球技術影響力。開發與運用人工智慧所帶來的競爭壓力，會加劇災難性後果的風險，因為倉促行事與敵對心態均會削弱安全性—這是任何國家都無法擺脫的危險。因此，在這場人工智慧競賽中取得成功必須有好的戰略，使其能在多個領域同時推進，並同時管理好不受控制人工智慧的安全風險。

作為整體戰略的一部分，華府必須盡全力，全盤瞭解矽谷、中共及世界各地新興人工智慧中心的人工智慧發展。全然的意料之外可能意謂著未能意識到新型威脅的出現，或是錯過領先中共運用人工智慧的機會。為防止這種狀況，美國政府必須與國內產業領袖維持緊密聯繫，並密切留意海外即將出現的技術突破。美國商務部（Commerce Department）日前將旗下的人工智慧安全研究所（AI Safety Institute）改名為美國人工智慧標準與創新中心（U.S. Center for AI Standards and Innovation），專注於與業界合作研究與測試尖端人工智慧，誠然是朝正確方向邁出的一步。國家安全部門與機構也應隨時掌握最新的尖端人工智慧發展，並探索其潛在的使用案例。同樣地，情報界必須擴大其對國外人工智慧發展的監控，特別要關注中共的進展與目標，以及中東地區新興人工智慧的發展趨勢。
川普政府也應尋找加快尖端人工智慧發展的方法。政府必須確保人工智慧公司在發展與運用人工智慧模型時，能獲得所需資源，其中包括強大的運算能力（即半導體）、高品質的數據、世界級的人才及充足的能源供應。重要的是不可在此過程中產生新的問題；例如，在不加劇氣候變遷的前提下，滿足人工智慧日益增長的能源需求，因此華府應該投資如核能等更清潔的能源。
華府亦必須捍衛美國的科技優勢。為確保人工智慧的進展不會被競爭對手迅速複製，美國政府需要對先進半導體與製造設備等技術實施嚴格管制，加強研究實驗室與資料中心的安全措施，以防止間諜活動與智慧財產竊盜，並要求雲端運算平臺進行嚴格的使用者驗證，以免在不知情的狀況下成為幫助對手勢力推進技術發展的工具。
為使美國在創新上保持領先地位，同時維護國家利益，美國政府必須發展一種可擴展且適應性強的公私合作模式，並與研發尖端人工智慧的公司合作。這些舉措有助於美國政府提升對先進人工智慧的採用，並推廣審慎的安全實務。美國的人工智慧公司若能取得與對手相關的敏感政府情報，將可從中受益，而公部門與私部門皆可從共同開發強化國家安全的人工智慧應用中受益，例如先進的網路安全與生物防禦工具。

隨著中共利用人工智慧與機器人逐步擴大其工業產能，華府的決策者同樣必須將人工智慧的應用擴展至科技領域以外。川普政府應與美國國會並肩合作，啟動一項專門的「工業人工智慧」倡議，加速機器人與人工智慧在製造、物流、能源及基礎建設產業等領域的研究、發展及投資。美國政府可以透過稅收抵免、創新補助及公私部門先導計畫，鼓勵工廠、倉庫及交通轉運站整合人工智慧驅動系統，以彌平美國尖端的軟體能力與落後的工廠生產線間之落差。

決策者亦必須採取行動，幫助那些在產業界因人工智慧而面臨失業的勞工。這意謂著要大幅提高對理工科教育、職業訓練、再訓練及技能提升計畫的投資—有助於因產線自動化而失業的勞工快速轉換跑道，從事諸如機器人維護或人工智慧系統管理的新角色。當經濟以人工智慧為核心，為企業提供明確規範並保護勞工，勞動法規亦須有所更新。因為企業增加運用演算法排定輪班班表，且愈來愈多員工採取短期約聘合約，工資與工時相關法律應與時俱進，以確保員工的薪資能透明、公平，及工作時間明確。職場安全規範同樣需要修改，納入廠區人機互動的安全標準。加強失業補助與其他形式的直接收入補助，以幫助因自動化而遭遇重大影響的勞工，相關舉措對於緩解日後大量失業勞工所造成的動盪情勢至關重要。
決策者必須採取行動，幫助未來在產業界因人工智慧而面臨失業的勞工。。(Source: shutterstock)

如果未來美國要領導全球人工智慧科技生態系統，則必須在富裕國家以外的地區提供先進人工智慧與數據中心。為了在開發中國家與中共「比下有餘」的人工智慧系統競爭，川普政府應探討公私部門合作計畫的可能性，向這些國家的開發者與創業者提供充分的美國雲端運算系統資源。美國政府應透過國際開發金融公司（International Development Finance Corporation）等相關機構，增加有政府背書的金融手段—如低利貸款、貸款擔保、股權投資、政治風險保險及稅收優惠。這些激勵措施應著重於重要新興市場數位基礎設施的建立，包括巴西、迦納、印度、印尼、肯亞、墨西哥、奈及利亞、菲律賓及越南等國。
最後，川普政府必須採取措施來降低最壞情況的風險—並為這類突發事件發生時完成準備。政府應針對人工智慧濫用或超級智慧失控所發生的災難，進行兵棋推演與危機模擬。此舉能讓高階領袖有機會演練危機的應對措施，找出不足之處，並在壓力下改善決策。

不僅如此，美國與中共身負重大義務，應彼此合作以降低人工智慧的風險。1962年，古巴飛彈危機之後，美國與蘇聯在核武競賽上建立起防護機制。1970年，美蘇兩國在《防止核擴散條約》（Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty）的談判中進行合作，雙方都意識到失控的核武競賽可能會將人類推向滅絕邊緣。如今，華府與北京須在人工智慧競賽與合作之間取得微妙的平衡點。美「中」兩國可以透過雙邊協議，分享人工智慧事件資訊，並針對人工智慧安全、控管及符合人類價值觀等方面交換最佳實務作法。更進一步的討論應著重於如何處理通用人工智慧濫用或失控之想定。
如果只是把美「中」間之人工智慧競賽視為單一戰場，這將忽略了這場敵對關係的複雜性。挑戰並不僅是贏得一場決定性戰役的勝利，而是在多重戰場保持上風，其競賽結果將會牽動國際權力的平衡。在這些深度交織的科技與戰略人工智慧競賽領域中步步為營，華府必須採取全面性戰略。要是無法做到，就算在一場競賽中取勝，仍可能會在另一場競賽中產生弱點—而忽視任何一場競賽，都有可能造成無可挽回的後果，削弱美國的全球地位。

The Real AI Race
America Needs More Than Innovation to Compete With China
Colin H. Kahl and Jim Mitre
COLIN H. KAHL is Steven C. Hazy Senior Fellow at Stanford University’s Center for International Security and Cooperation and a Senior Adviser at RAND.
JIM MITRE is Vice President and Director of RAND Global and Emerging Risks.
The Real AI Race
America Needs More Than Innovation to Compete With China
Colin H. Kahl and Jim Mitre

Discussions in Washington about artificial intelligence increasingly turn to how the United States can win the AI race with China. One of President Donald Trump’s first acts on returning to office was to sign an executive order declaring the need to “sustain and enhance America’s global AI dominance.” At the Paris AI Action Summit in February, Vice President JD Vance emphasized the administration’s commitment to ensuring that “American AI technology continues to be the gold standard worldwide.” And in May, David Sacks, Trump’s AI and crypto czar, cited the need “to win the AI race” to justify exporting advanced AI chips to the United Arab Emirates and Saudi Arabia.

Given the prospect that AI could transform the power and prosperity of nations in the decades to come, it is better to win the race than lose it. But determining who is ahead depends on what it means to win. A common definition is being the first to cross the threshold of artificial general intelligence, which in basic terms is an AI model that is as smart or smarter than the top human experts across a wide range of cognitive tasks. AGI could unlock extraordinary breakthroughs in science, technology, and economic productivity—and the first country to develop it could reap disproportionate benefits.

But the race to AGI is not the only critical race in the AI contest. Militaries and intelligence agencies must harness AI’s transformative potential and mitigate its disruptive effects. Similarly, countries stand to gain a competitive edge if they can adopt AI at scale across the economy and society. Governments are also battling to create and own the standards, supply chains, and infrastructure that will undergird the global technological ecosystem. And all must avoid a race to the bottom in AI safety by working—sometimes together—to manage security risks from misused or rogue AI.

Taking these additional AI races into account makes the United States’ position look precarious. Although U.S. companies maintain a meaningful—if narrowing—lead at the frontier of AI research and development, Washington could lose other AI races. China has considerable advantages, and neither superpower seems eager to cooperate to avoid catastrophe. And given AI’s world-changing potential, the stakes are profound: losing risks relegating the United States to economic dependence, military vulnerability, and diminished global leadership. That bleak future can still be avoided. But the United States will need to muster a coherent AI strategy, one that balances innovation, integration, and risk mitigation to translate the country’s immense technological dynamism into enduring strategic advantage.
THE RACE TO INNOVATE

The race to AGI is the most visible and immediate of the AI contests. Private companies such as OpenAI, Anthropic, and Google DeepMind in the United States and DeepSeek in China are rushing to innovate, supported by their respective governments. No one knows exactly how the technology will evolve. Large language models could be the first signs of emerging AGI, or true AGI could manifest suddenly when AI models pass a certain threshold. Either way, AGI has enough potential to transform the sources of national power and competitiveness that the world’s two AI leaders have a substantial interest in securing a first-mover advantage.

American AI labs currently have a discernible edge, helped along by semiconductor export controls designed to maintain the United States’ computational advantage over China. But this lead is fragile. China’s domestic innovation, circumvention of export controls, and intellectual property theft have kept the country in a close second place. Its leading AI companies, such as DeepSeek, are developing technologies that trail their U.S. counterparts by mere months. And Beijing’s centralized approach might help it nurture, consolidate, and harness private-sector innovations more quickly than Washington can.

The United States’ open system, meanwhile, fosters innovation but is inherently vulnerable to espionage and the rapid diffusion of algorithmic advances. Breakthroughs in algorithmic design or alternative paradigms for AI development could diminish the importance of U.S. semiconductor dominance, and their spread could enable China’s AI labs to leapfrog American competitors. The Trump administration, driven by other political priorities, is also pulling back investment in basic AI research and development and discouraging talented foreign nationals from working in the United States, potentially setting back American AI efforts over the next several years.

The U.S. private sector, moreover, responds to commercial imperatives that are not always consistent with national priorities. AI firms, for example, will be tempted to build AI computing power wherever there is available energy infrastructure—whether or not it is based in the United States. Favorable regulatory environments and abundant resources in the Middle East are already proving attractive. The world’s first five-gigawatt AI data center cluster will be built in the UAE, not the United States—a development enabled by the Trump administration’s recent decision to export hundreds of thousands of leading-edge AI chips to Abu Dhabi. Washington does benefit from this arrangement, and U.S. firms including OpenAI and Microsoft are slated to operate most of the data centers’ capacity. But moving crucial infrastructure offshore, where security may be lax, could also provide a backdoor for China and other competitors to acquire advanced computing resources and AI models.

Even if the United States can hold on to its lead in the innovation race, that may not be enough. Current market trends suggest that frontier AI models are becoming so widely accessible and undifferentiated that they give no one a clear technological edge. If that trend holds when AGI emerges, victory will depend on effective AI adoption—and there is no guarantee the United States will come out on top.
SECURING THE EDGE

In the realm of national security, effective AI adoption requires both understanding the capabilities enabled (and threats posed) by frontier AI and integrating AI into existing structures in ways that secure a decisive military edge. Integration of AI promises to enhance intelligence processing, accelerate data-driven decision-making, optimize logistics and resource allocation, enable sophisticated autonomous systems, and possibly even lead to the development of a “wonder weapon”—such as a cyberweapon that could cripple an adversary’s critical infrastructure and command and control or, used defensively, make a country invulnerable to cyberattacks.

The U.S. government and private industry need to work together to achieve AI integration, but their current cooperation remains troublingly limited. National security agencies lack early access to the latest AI models, which would speed up the process of incorporating the latest technologies into their workflows. Partnerships between leading AI labs and the Pentagon and other national security agencies are only in nascent stages. And lengthy procurement cycles, operational cultures that are resistant to change, a lack of infrastructure and data, and misunderstandings about what AI can achieve—both underestimating and overestimating its abilities—hamper the government’s ability to take full advantage of innovations coming out of Silicon Valley. Although these problems are widely acknowledged, fixing them has proved difficult.

China’s authoritarian system, meanwhile, eases civil-military integration, providing it with a structural edge in AI adoption. State mandates ensure that technological advances are rapidly translated into military and intelligence capabilities. The People’s Liberation Army has embraced AI and is actively seeking contributions from the commercial and academic sectors. Making use of AI competitions and public purchasing platforms designed to translate civilian AI research to military applications, it plans to field “algorithmic warfare” and “network-centric warfare” capabilities by 2030. More than merely using algorithms in weapons systems, this entails a transition to a new type of warfare in which military superiority depends on the speed, sophistication, and reliability of those algorithms.

Remaining on the cutting edge of innovation is necessary but not sufficient to win the race in the national security space. The United States could produce scientific and technological breakthrough after breakthrough but still fail to recognize the point at which AI opens a new technological pathway to a revolutionary military or intelligence capability. Washington’s bureaucratic structures, designed for incremental improvements to existing systems, often make it difficult to imagine left-field possibilities for emerging technologies. Beijing’s centralized decision-making system, in comparison, could identify and exploit a disruptive pathway much faster, potentially leaving the United States technologically superior but strategically outmaneuvered.
THE INTEGRATION IMPERATIVE

The winner of the AI race will also need to integrate AI into the national economy—to ensure that AI is widely accessible and is diffused across the education, energy, finance, health, logistics, and manufacturing sectors. The U.S. technology companies that drive consumer and business AI applications, a vibrant venture capital ecosystem that funds innovation, relatively high digital literacy, and extensive digital infrastructure all provide the United States notable advantages. Yet success is not guaranteed. If corporate and governmental actors at all levels fail to create the right incentives for integration and build sufficient public trust in AI, the private sector could struggle to adopt AI quickly enough to capitalize on the benefits of enhanced productivity and new value creation. There is also a danger that AI will not simply augment human labor but replace it. Anthropic’s CEO, Dario Amodei, has recently warned that AI could lead to as much as 20 percent unemployment in the United States within five years—an outcome that could deeply destabilize both the economy and American society.

Meanwhile, China may be poised to perform surprisingly well in the race for economic adoption. Chinese business leaders are already more focused on AI applications than on developing AI models. DeepSeek’s open-source models, for example, are driving down costs for all Chinese AI models, which enables more businesses to experiment with the technology. This could give China an edge in creating game-changing products. The Chinese government is also less exposed to the political consequences of AI replacing labor. Whereas automating jobs raises alarm in Washington, Beijing could even welcome AI adoption as a solution to China’s labor shortages brought by a rapidly aging and shrinking population.

Even if the United States adopts AI across its economy as aggressively as China does, it may lose the overall race if China is better positioned to capitalize on the manufacturing advances enabled by AI, particularly in the realm of robotics. China leads the world in industrial robot installations: Chinese manufacturers purchased half the global market share in 2024, and the country’s robots per employee significantly exceeded the global average. Extreme automation is becoming more common in the manufacturing sector with the proliferation of “dark factories,” such as the electronics company Xiaomi’s smartphone facility that operates 24/7 without human workers. As AI makes strides in spatial reasoning and embodied intelligence—AI that enables robots to interact with and learn from their physical environment—factory robots may become able to perform a much wider array of complex physical tasks.

Although U.S. firms excel in software and services—areas that are also expected to make significant productivity gains as a result of AI adoption—the United States has ceded ground to China in recent decades in physical industries, including manufacturing, logistics, energy, and infrastructure. With its state-driven industrial policy and massive manufacturing base, China can deploy AI at scale within these sectors and might unleash dramatic productivity gains that lead it to finally surpass the U.S. economy.
STACKING THE DECK

The world’s tech powers are also racing to provide the digital infrastructure that will undergird the global development, deployment, and use of AI. Although this is primarily a competition between the United States and China, other established tech powers (such as France, Japan, the Netherlands, South Korea, Taiwan, and the United Kingdom) and ambitious emerging players (such as Brazil, India, Saudi Arabia, and the UAE) are joining the contest, too. Each participant aims to control the data, the chips and data centers, and the foundational models required for AI use, as well as exert influence over global AI norms and standards. As Sacks, the AI and crypto czar, recently put it, “If 80 percent of the world uses the American tech stack, that’s winning. If 80 percent uses Chinese tech, that’s losing.”

Export controls on semiconductor chips have given the United States a meaningful edge. U.S. companies have access to the chips they need for computational power, and much of the world wants U.S. chips because they are the best on offer. The Trump administration is seeking to capitalize on this advantage by “flooding the zone” with U.S. chips and data centers, starting in partner countries such as Saudia Arabia and the UAE. The idea is to lock in the use of U.S. technology in places where market forces encourage massive investments in digital infrastructure.

But in countries with lower incomes, fewer customers, and less basic infrastructure such as broadband connectivity and electricity, Washington’s strategy of following market forces will lead to underinvestment. This is the dynamic across a broad group of countries in Africa, Latin America, the Middle East, and South and Southeast Asia that are turning to AI to boost their economic growth. China is positioned to outcompete the United States in these places by providing less advanced and significantly cheaper AI models—as well as subsidizing the physical and digital infrastructure needed to run them. It may not currently be able to export any top-of-the-line chips, but for many developing countries where cost and accessibility are more important than cutting-edge performance, China’s “good enough” offerings could prove highly attractive.

Ceding these emerging markets risks a future in which the United States wins the technological race at the frontier but surrenders leadership of the global AI ecosystem to China. The consequences for Washington extend beyond lost geopolitical influence and commercial opportunities. Chinese AI models and infrastructure frequently embody digital authoritarian values, enabling Beijing to export mechanisms of state control and shape historical and political narratives beyond its borders. They facilitate surveillance by powering facial and voice recognition systems and analyzing vast amounts of data to monitor individuals and flag “suspicious” behavior. They automatically censor content critical of the Chinese Communist Party or related to sensitive topics such as Tiananmen Square, Taiwan, Hong Kong, the Uyghurs, or Chinese leader Xi Jinping. Their algorithms also curate and disseminate pro-Chinese propaganda. In contrast, American AI models generally reflect stronger commitments to democratic norms, transparency, privacy safeguards, user choice, and data protection frameworks, helping reduce opportunities for government abuse. A critical step toward ensuring the technologies shaping modern life across the world align with democratic values is for Washington to proactively incentivize American AI firms to invest and build infrastructure in developing countries.

Poor policy choices could set the United States back in the race to build and manage the world’s AI infrastructure. Overly restrictive export controls could alienate allies or drive countries currently on the fence toward Chinese products. Conversely, applying too little control over advanced AI chips could inadvertently create opportunities for Chinese companies to acquire or remotely access them, potentially accelerating China’s technological innovation. And if Washington cannot articulate a compelling vision for technological governance—one that carefully balances national security with economic openness and democratic values—potential international partners may turn elsewhere. China is not just selling AI; it offers a comprehensive toolkit for rapid modernization on financially and politically appealing terms to a substantial portion of the world. For a developing country eager to harness AI for economic gains and improved governance, the Chinese offer is often the most practical and readily available path forward.
A RACE TO THE BOTTOM?

Even as the United States and China compete in the AI race, they cannot forget that AGI and other highly capable AI models create potential threats. It is imperative that neither competitor allows its rapid development and deployment of AI to make a disaster more likely. A nonstate actor or rogue state weaponizing AI models, unintentional military escalation caused by AI, or a loss of control of superintelligent systems could prove catastrophic. Preventing such outcomes requires that AI powers avoid cutting corners on safety in their haste to compete.

The most pressing near-term catastrophic risks are that nonstate actors with access to advanced AI systems could launch large-scale cyberattacks that devastate financial systems or design and release highly lethal and transmissible pathogens. These hazards are no longer confined to the realm of science fiction. Companies at the forefront of AI development have predicted that their internally defined thresholds for dangerous capabilities—measured as “uplift,” or the degree to which an AI model significantly enhances a malicious actor’s abilities—are likely to be crossed this year. Another rapidly approaching threat is the potential emergence of a superintelligence misaligned with human values or intentions, pursuing actions that endanger human well-being because of flawed design, ambiguous instructions, or unforeseen consequences. Growing evidence of frontier AI models exhibiting deceptive or scheming behaviors makes this risk increasingly credible.

Both Washington and Beijing have an interest in preventing the proliferation of dangerous AI capabilities and the emergence of rogue AGI. This common ground creates an opportunity for cooperation between the two AI superpowers—even amid their intense technological competition—to better understand risks of misuse and misalignment and to identify and develop effective mitigation measures.

For Washington, seeking ways to mitigate threats from AI—an imperative the Trump administration has recognized—is sound policy regardless of what other AI powers do. Even if rogue AI does not lead to global calamity, a major AI-related incident originating from the United States, whether accidental or through negligence, would undermine confidence in American technology. And if the United States is seen as unable to manage the immense power of AI, its global leadership and moral authority would be called into question, and China could exploit the resulting power vacuum by promising stability and control.
RECIPE FOR SUCCESS

The trajectories of the various AI races between China and the United States are tightly intertwined. Winning the race to AGI development, for example, will boost the leading country’s national security, economic vitality, and global technological influence. And the competitive pressures unleashed by the races to develop and adopt AI exacerbate the risk of a catastrophic outcome as haste and rivalry undercut safety—a danger no country can outrun. Success in the AI race therefore requires a strategy that advances progress across several fronts simultaneously while managing the security risks of unchecked AI.

As part of a holistic strategy, Washington must make every effort to avoid being caught off guard by AI advances in Silicon Valley, China, and emerging AI hubs around the world. Being surprised could mean failing to recognize the emergence of new threats or missing opportunities to capitalize on AI progress ahead of China. To prevent this, the U.S. government must maintain close communication with domestic industry leaders and closely monitor imminent technological breakthroughs abroad. The Commerce Department’s repurposing of its AI Safety Institute, now called the U.S. Center for AI Standards and Innovation, to focus on working with industry to research and test frontier AI is a step in the right direction. National security departments and agencies, too, should remain apprised of the latest frontier AI developments and explore potential use cases. Likewise, the intelligence community must expand its monitoring of foreign AI efforts, particularly focusing on China’s advancements and objectives, as well as those of emerging AI powers in the Middle East.

The Trump administration should also identify ways to facilitate frontier AI development. It must ensure that AI companies have access to the resources they need for AI model development and deployment, including vast computational power (in the form of semiconductors), high-quality data, world-class talent, and sufficient energy supplies. It will be important not to create new problems in the process; to meet AI’s growing energy demands without exacerbating climate change, for example, Washington should invest in cleaner energy sources such as nuclear power.

Washington must defend U.S. technological superiority, too. To ensure that AI advancements are not rapidly replicated by competitors, the U.S. government will need to enforce stringent controls over technologies such as advanced semiconductors and manufacturing equipment, strengthen security measures at research labs and data centers to prevent espionage and intellectual property theft, and require rigorous user verification on cloud computing platforms so that they do not become unwitting tools for an adversary’s technological advancement.

To keep the United States at the forefront of innovation while safeguarding national interests, the U.S. government must develop a scalable and adaptive public-private partnership model to cooperate with companies working on frontier AI. These initiatives should help the government ramp up its adoption of advanced AI and promote prudent security practices. American AI companies can benefit from access to sensitive government intelligence about adversaries attempting to target them, and both the public sector and the private sector can benefit from co-developing AI applications that can enhance national security, such as advanced cybersecurity and biodefense tools.

As China expands its industrial capacity using AI and robotics, policymakers in Washington must also broaden AI adoption beyond the technology sector. The Trump administration should work with Congress to launch a dedicated “industrial AI” initiative to accelerate research, development, and investment in robotics and AI deployment across the manufacturing, logistics, energy, and infrastructure sectors. With tax credits, innovation grants, and public-private pilot projects, the government can incentivize factories, warehouses, and transportation hubs to integrate AI-driven systems, bridging the gap between the United States’ cutting-edge software capabilities and its lagging factory floors.

Policymakers must also act now to help the workers who will lose their jobs to AI in these industrial sectors. This means significantly increasing investments in STEM education, vocational training, and retraining and upskilling programs—services that would enable workers displaced by automation to swiftly transition into new roles, such as robot maintenance or AI system supervision. To provide clarity for businesses and protections for workers in an AI-centric economy, labor laws and regulations also require updates. As companies increasingly use algorithms to schedule work shifts and more employees work on short-term contracts, wage-and-hour laws should be modernized to ensure transparent, fair compensation and clearly defined working hours. Workplace safety guidelines will need to be revised to incorporate standards for safe human-robot interaction on factory floors. Strengthening unemployment benefits and other forms of direct income support for people disproportionately affected by automation will also be crucial to mitigating the potentially destabilizing consequences of significant labor displacement.

If the United States is to lead the global AI technology ecosystem, it will also need to provide advanced AI and data centers to more than just wealthy countries. To compete with China’s “good enough” AI systems across the developing world, the Trump administration should explore public-private partnerships to offer generous access to U.S. cloud computing systems to researchers and entrepreneurs in these countries. It should also scale up government-backed financial tools—such as low-interest loans, loan guarantees, equity investments, political risk insurance, and tax incentives—through agencies such as the International Development Finance Corporation. These incentives should be geared toward building digital infrastructure in important emerging markets, such as in Brazil, Ghana, India, Indonesia, Kenya, Mexico, Nigeria, the Philippines, and Vietnam.

Finally, the Trump administration must take steps to reduce the risk of worst-case scenarios—and prepare for those contingencies should they arise. It should run tabletop exercises and crisis simulations of cases involving catastrophic misuse of AI or rogue superintelligence. Doing so would give senior leaders opportunities to rehearse crisis responses, identify gaps in readiness, and improve their decision-making under pressure.

The United States and China, moreover, have a profound obligation to themselves and the world to collaborate to reduce AI risks. Following the 1962 Cuban missile crisis, the United States and the Soviet Union built guardrails around their nuclear competition. They cooperated on negotiations for the 1970 Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty, recognizing that an uncontrolled race to the nuclear frontier could send humanity hurtling off a cliff. Washington and Beijing today need to chart a similarly narrow path between AI competition and collaboration. They could start with a bilateral agreement to share AI incident information and exchange best practices on AI safety, control, and alignment with human values. Further talks should focus on how to handle scenarios of misused or uncontrolled AGI.

The notion of a singular AI race between the United States and China fails to capture the true complexity of the rivalry unfolding today. The challenge is to win not one definitive contest but a multifront competition whose outcome will shape the international balance of power. Navigating these deeply intertwined domains of technological and strategic AI competition demands that Washington adopt a holistic strategy. Without it, success in one race could create vulnerabilities in another—and neglecting any of them risks irreparably weakening the United States’ global position.

The Real Stakes of the AI Race
What America, China, and Middle Powers Stand to Gain and Lose
Reva Goujon

A sense that global technology competition is becoming a zero-sum game, and that the remainder of the twenty-first century will be made in the winner’s image, pervades in Washington, Beijing, and boardrooms worldwide. This angst feeds ambitious industrial policies, precautionary regulations, and multibillion-dollar investments. Yet even as governments and private industry race for supremacy in artificial intelligence, none of them possess a clear vision of what “winning” looks like or what geopolitical returns their investments will yield.

Much more than computing dominance is at stake; the struggle for AI primacy between the United States, China, middle powers, and Big Tech is fundamentally a competition over whose vision of the world order will reign supreme. For the United States, AI is a new frontier on which it must maintain its global technological dominance. As U.S. policymakers deploy a regulatory arsenal to cripple China’s technology development and stay ahead, China is mobilizing the power of the state to close the gap. At the same time, middle powers trying to avoid coming under the shadow of either superpower, along with tech companies devoted to the global diffusion of technology through open markets, see AI development paving the path to a multipolar world.

Already, U.S. technology controls and China’s escalatory response are creating a snowball effect: as the United States, bent on preserving tech primacy, resorts to more aggressive measures to throttle Chinese AI development, a cornered China will hunt for leverage over the United States, including, potentially, in security flash points such as the Taiwan Strait. Middle powers and tech companies, meanwhile, will strive to build AI systems and applications outside the confines of great-power rivalry—both looking to stake a claim to the new technological order even as they risk getting caught in the crossfire. As the tenor of the global AI race grows existential, the high-stakes wagers of tech titans and world powers risk geopolitical combustion.
PROTECT THE LEAD

The United States is building its AI strategy on the assumption that it can preserve its hegemony offensively, through a rate of technological innovation that outpaces the rest of the world, and defensively, through far-reaching technology controls aimed at hobbling China, its biggest geopolitical challenger. Export controls and investment restrictions are designed to cut off the flow of goods, capital, and technological know-how from Beijing. Washington’s strategy assumes that China is in structural economic decline, its statist approach stifling the animal spirits of an economy at the mercy of the Communist Party and its general secretary, Xi Jinping.

It also puts enormous stock in the the pervasiveness and competitiveness of U.S. technology. Washington is betting that partners who may resist aligning with its protectionist strategy will ultimately cast their lot with U.S. technology and the promise of Western AI innovation rather than gamble on China closing the gap and risk running afoul of U.S. sanctions. After all, U.S. technology and intellectual property dominate every level of the AI industry. Nvidia’s AI accelerators increase computing power by orders of magnitude, driving the AI revolution; U.S. cloud service providers, such as Amazon Web Services, Microsoft Azure, and Google Cloud Platform, distribute massive computing resources and cloud infrastructure; and companies such as Google, Meta, OpenAI, Anthropic, and xAI have developed the foundational AI models that companies all over the world will rely on to fine-tune their AI applications.

The United States holds unique leverage in this early stage in the development of AI. Large-scale AI models, particularly in generative AI, which uses patterns learned from existing data to create new content, require immense computational power and vast amounts of data, the resources for which few companies outside the United States possess. The United States’ lead in this industry is not an accident; it has attracted more than $328 billion in investment over the past five years to promote AI development and foster a culture in which risk-taking is rewarded. Building on the Biden administration’s suite of industrial policies expanding domestic chip manufacturing, the incoming Trump administration has touted an “AI Manhattan Project” to turbocharge a U.S.-led AI industrial revolution.

U.S. tech hegemony is not impregnable, however. The development and diffusion of AI technology could dilute the United States’ current advantages. Generative AI development to date has largely been focused on obtaining the huge amounts of computational power, data, and energy required to train large-scale AI models, for which access to the world’s most advanced chips has been critical. U.S. dominance of the production of these chips through companies such as Nvidia and AMD has enabled the U.S. government to tighten export controls to severely restrict that access. The United States is trying to hobble China’s domestic AI development, in particular, by cutting off its supply of high-end chips and the equipment and components needed to manufacture advanced node semiconductors.

But Washington finds itself in an awkward phase of that strategy. Despite a barrage of U.S.-led chip controls, Huawei’s HiSilicon and SMIC, China’s leading chip designer and manufacturer, respectively, leading China’s push for self-reliance, are producing high-performance AI accelerators used in data centers, such as the Ascend 910C processor, which is nearly as advanced as Nvidia’s H100 and A100 chips. Still, Chinese production has been far less efficient than that of the Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC), which uses state-of-the-art manufacturing technology to produce cutting-edge chips.

Chinese engineers are being flooded with state resources to innovate their way out of U.S.-imposed constraints on chip production. AI development is shifting away from maximization of computational power for training large-scale models and toward optimization to get pretrained models to generate more sophisticated responses to queries. Nvidia and other leading companies are already focusing less on shrinking transistor nodes at the atomic level and more on performance gains across the full AI system, from the design of the chips themselves to the cooling systems used to integrate the hardware in data centers. When launching the first round of chip controls in October 2022, U.S. policymakers assumed that process node miniaturization was the fundamental chokepoint to “freeze in place” Chinese chip production. But with Huawei leading China’s self-reliance efforts, China has demonstrated that it still has the process engineering ability, manpower, and sheer tenacity to keep up with industry advances in performance optimization.

Concern about the United States’ ability to create a wide enough lead over China in AI development will lead to blunter controls, less patience for partners that do not align their own policies with U.S. export restrictions, and swifter application of extraterritorial measures. In December, the U.S. Department of Commerce released a package of semiconductor controls that exemplifies this approach, using far-reaching restrictions to force partners into alignment and to throttle Chinese production. But if Chinese companies are still able to scale their computing power, and gaps in partner alignment on chip controls remain, Washington will likely adopt blocking sanctions on Huawei and expand trade restrictions to include China’s AI tech champions. The potential blow to the Chinese economy and Beijing’s geopolitical ambition would heighten the stakes of the AI and chip war.
PLAYING CATCH-UP

China assumes that it is on equal geopolitical footing with the United States in a bipolar world. For Beijing, AI development is both the path to preserving parity with Washington and the antidote to its domestic economic challenges. China has intrinsic strengths: the sheer size of its population and the country’s massive industries give it an enormous well of data to draw from in training AI models and the opportunity to pioneer AI applications for manufacturing. Thanks in part to their large pools of employees willing to work long hours, Chinese tech champions such as Alibaba, Baidu, DeepSeek AI, Huawei, and Tencent are competitive with U.S. peers in large language model development and cloud infrastructure. China has also put enormous resources into optimizing power generation for data centers; it is now the fastest developer of energy generation in the world. Beijing is betting that high levels of state funding for AI-powered industries will pay off, especially if overreaching trade and technology controls alienate U.S. partners, drive them into China’s arms, and open up new markets for Chinese technology. From China’s perspective, this strategy is the country’s best (and only) hope to arrest recent economic malaise and to avoid subordination to the United States.

But China also faces significant vulnerabilities, most notably in its ability to develop the AI hardware needed to keep pace with the United States. As U.S. technologists create ever more efficient AI chips and dynamic AI models, China’s leading foundries will have to devote considerable resources just to maintain their chip production capabilities as tightening U.S. controls restrict their access to key components. This diverted energy will make it more difficult to keep pace with U.S. innovation. Chinese AI developers will face a dual challenge of seeking breakthrough innovation amid stifling U.S. tech controls while also complying with the nebulous Communist Party mandate that AI models “uphold socialist values.”

U.S.-led chip controls have not been impenetrable to date, but more aggressive U.S. controls could reduce the ability of foreign toolmakers, chip designers, and foundries to maintain a foothold in China’s chip market. If the United States builds on current de-risking momentum and coordinates with partners effectively, China could find itself increasingly excluded from emerging U.S.-led technology and trade blocs that reserve access to data and critical digital infrastructure for like-minded countries. Any potential reorganization of trade blocs would be disastrous for China’s ability to expand to foreign markets, especially at a time when its tech giants are relying on overseas growth to compensate for the structural decline of the domestic economy.

If China struggles to keep pace in chip development, and Beijing fears that this will make it fall further behind the United States in the AI race, the state could direct Chinese tech juggernauts to centralize and scale their computing resources. But such a step would expose China further to U.S. tech controls. For now, Huawei’s HiSilicon is the country’s preeminent AI chip designer. But Huawei is also the Chinese tech company most heavily sanctioned by the United States. Huawei’s chips are manufactured by SMIC, China’s state-owned foundry, which, like Huawei, is now subject to U.S. foreign direct product rule restrictions. These are designed to prevent components from any country from going to SMIC plants where advanced chips are being manufactured. If the government orders Chinese AI model developers to pool their resources to support the state’s AI development, they, too, would become prime targets for severe U.S. sanctions that would undermine their efforts to expand their market shares outside China. The United States has already expanded export control categories to include the gray area of firms engaged in military “support” activities. The justification for broader controls is already baked into U.S. rules and is waiting to be deployed.
GOLDEN TICKET?

Middle powers and Big Tech leaders have yet another outlook on the global AI competition. Many of them see the diffusion of technology as enabling the new era of multipolarity. With the United States and China locked in a contest for AI primacy, countries such as France, Saudi Arabia, Singapore, and the United Arab Emirates have started to build sovereign AI systems that make use of their national strengths: control over data access, intimate knowledge of their respective economies, and expertise in their respective languages and cultures to mitigate bias. The UAE, for example, may deploy up to $100 billion over the next few years as part of the country’s goal to be a global AI leader by 2031. These gains reflect middle powers’ status anxiety, as well as their recognition of the opportunity to carve out niches for themselves amid U.S.-Chinese competition.

Nvidia’s founder, Jensen Huang, has been quick to acknowledge the mix of anxiety and aspiration among middle powers. He has toured Canada, France, India, Japan, Malaysia, Singapore, and Vietnam, delivering the same seductive message: every country needs its own sovereign AI to reflect its language, culture, and ambitions. Meta, meanwhile, has open-sourced its Llama large language model, sharing its blueprint for building the model with the world. Open-sourcing makes it easier for the technology to diffuse across borders. It also may erode the competitive advantages of Meta’s closed-model rivals, including OpenAI’s GPT, Anthropic’s Claude, and Google’s Gemini. Unlike their competitors, which have erected proprietary walls around their technology to protect their innovation, open-source advocates such as Meta hope an expanded ecosystem of developers will encourage widespread adoption of and innovation on their own platform.

For most countries, however, achieving AI sovereignty is more complicated than tech leaders make it out to be. Middle powers can build AI infrastructure, but they will likely be doing so with U.S. semiconductors, cloud infrastructure, and a heavy reliance on U.S. talent and U.S.-origin AI foundation models. The ubiquity of U.S. technology enables Washington to impose conditions on partners, such as excluding Chinese firms from their supply chains and preventing Chinese access to U.S.-built AI systems, on the grounds that Chinese companies pose national security risks.

Finding the optimal level of AI regulation will also be a challenge. Many tech leaders prefer a light touch on AI regulation to clear the path for private industry to innovate without getting bogged down by heavy compliance requirements, but their appeals may not always align with U.S. government priorities to impose restrictions that block out China and countries willing to work with China. For example, open-source business models alarm security-minded policymakers who fear that unrestricted access could enable adversaries to more easily develop or exploit sensitive technology. Meanwhile, middle powers lacking a strong domestic tech base will try to assert their relevance by passing regulation that creates a de facto global standard for AI development. In August, the EU AI Act came into force as the world’s first comprehensive AI law. It was met with significant criticism, including from the former European Central Bank president Mario Draghi, who warned that the law’s “precautionary approach” to regulation would be onerous, and advised that deregulation is urgently needed to “close the innovation gap with the U.S. and China.”
CHIPS ON THE TABLE

With nothing less than competing visions for the world order at stake, competitors will do all they can to gain the upper hand. Unintended consequences will follow. U.S. regulators may be overzealous in their controls. If Washington pursues proposed quotas on the number of U.S.-made AI chips other countries are able to procure, for example, it may undermine its leverage to lock in strategic dependencies for U.S. technology in fast-growing markets. U.S. officials might also be underestimating the momentum of China’s technology innovation. Overconfident in the efficacy of export controls, they could prematurely see inefficiencies in SMIC chip production as evidence of their policies’ success, while domestic Chinese suppliers make strides with heavy state backing and Chinese foundation model developers such as DeepSeekAI and Alibaba pool enough high-end computing power to rival their U.S. peers.

If Washington comes to believe that the AI technology gap between the two superpowers is closing, it will push for blunter measures. This would likely entail imposing full blocking sanctions on Huawei and more draconian restrictions on Chinese AI tech champions. If China’s tech giants are denied markets abroad while its statist economic model is faltering at home, a cornered Beijing may interpret the United States’ moves as an existential threat, creating the conditions for the technology war to potentially spill into the security sphere.

China’s leadership could respond to intensified trade restrictions with escalatory moves elsewhere. Assuming that Washington would try to avoid direct war, Beijing could test its rival’s limits with more serious gray-zone maneuvers in the Taiwan Strait. For instance, China could establish a customs quarantine that effectively asserts the mainland’s writ over Taiwanese ports of entry and challenges Taiwan’s political sovereignty. Such a step would have dramatic consequences, not only for the future of semiconductor supply chains as assets and investment flee Taiwan but also for the balance of power in the Indo-Pacific.

For now, the unbridled optimism of technologists will keep the AI revolution moving forward, in hopes that the spread of the technology will transform humanity. At the same time, the anxiety of policymakers, who see economic and security risks lurking at every corner, will continue to drive efforts to channel AI competition toward zero-sum geopolitical goals. All recognize that power will accrue to those who hold the keys to AI development and deployment. As countries and tech giants jockey for position, the geopolitical tempest that ensues may overshadow the transformative potential of the technology.

chinese_title: 辨識深偽影像：關於人工智慧、決策及演算效能的兵棋推演
chinese_paragraphs: 推演想定初期，參演人員即發現以人工智慧（Artificial Intelligence, AI）建構之深度偽造（Deepfake，以下簡稱深偽）偵測工具存在演算法的限制。想定推演期間，參演人員親眼目睹此項問題降低偵測工具的效能與可靠度，導致資料評估結果與情報判斷效度不佳。推演過程中，參演人員遭遇各式各樣的決策挑戰。
就目前所知，此為同類型演練的首例。本文綜整推演計畫人員、首席科學家、研究團隊及參演學員之觀點，希望能拋磚引玉，促進對最佳實務作法更進一步的討論，以協助未來領導幹部在遭遇作戰環境的問題前，先行發掘新科技的可能影響。
2024年8月6日，維吉尼亞州蘭利─尤斯提斯（Langley-Eustis）聯合基地人工智慧素養課程推演期間，美空軍空中作戰司令部華內克（Justin Warnack，左）先生與布蘭德（Joseph Bland）三等士官長共同檢視狀況推演小卡。(Source: USAF/Madeline Herzog)
◎對演算法效能進行推演之緣由
人工智慧工具飛快納入國家安全與國防決策流程，但對於此類工具如何影響軍人的重要與軍事倫理相關決策，以及此類工具的弱點與限制，我們並未全然理解與妥擬應處作為。預應此類挑戰的最佳方式，就是在聯戰專業軍事教育（Joint Professional Military Education, JPME）課堂中實施推演，觀察此類工具在推演情況下的弱點與限制，並藉由參演學員的實際經驗，將推演的張力最大化。

2023年9月IQT實驗室與Luminos.Law法律事務共同設計的兵棋推演期間，美國國防大學資訊暨網路空間學院（College of Information and Cyberspace）探討聯戰專業軍事教育範疇內的運算法效能相關議題。就筆者所知，這是美國國防部人員首次在課堂環境中參與此類推演。本文摘錄關鍵要點與推演所得，包括演算法效能重要議題、推演本身的觀察（含兩位參演學員心得回饋），以及後續的建議流程與研究方向。

整體來說，這次推演經驗凸顯一項關鍵需求：必須持續發揮創意調整教學方法，以培養能夠運用、評估、指導、分配資源，並對人工智慧相關系統成果負責之高層決策者。儘管美國國防部早已闡述研發與運用人工智慧工具的架構，惟此舉並未納入未來領導幹部的教育訓練，讓彼等瞭解如何運用人工智慧技術，輔助重要與軍事倫理決策。隨著新興人工智慧工具逐漸融入決策支援體系，我們是否做好準備，面對人工智慧系統伴隨而來的不確定性與脆弱性？研究員、教育人員及未來領導幹部（學員）都希望找出解決方法。
◎演算法效能：瞭解潛在弱點
軟體皆會出錯，此情況在所難免。當機器學習與人工智慧納入軟體設計，就可能產生新的故障模式。舉例而言，目前許多研究發現，針對人工智慧模型與工具的新型「惡意」攻擊層出不窮。然而，此類「蓄意」攻擊並非唯一的注意事項。當前，許多人工智慧系統出錯並非蓄意為之，反而源自於（軟體）工程缺失、訓練數據不足或演算法限制。
人工智慧模型是根據既有的訓練數據產製成果，但該成果並不完善。也就是說，這些模型反映訓練數據與特徵提取方法的既存限制。正如統計學家博克斯（George Box）的名言：「所有模型皆有錯。」但是某些模型仍有用處。模型的限制不一定都令人擔憂，但某些限制會造成嚴重後果。

舉例而言，許多電腦視覺分類演算法（Computer Vision Classification Algorithm），皆奠基於隱含假設：訓練數據各等級（或種類）的樣本數應相同，才可供模型訓練與辨識。倘若實情並非如此，此模型針對某些等級（或種類）的預測正確率恐會更低。在人臉識別模型中，愈來愈多的學術文獻記載這種現象，由於訓練數據中深色皮膚的人臉樣本不足，因此人臉識別模型對特定族群的辨識成效持續不佳。
在美國，演算法所受限制，通常被視為民間公司之問題，而這些公司必須遵守國內反歧視法。在此種思維下，（演算法）所受之限制似乎與模型本身效能無關，後續危害卻與分析對象（即消費者）的權利息息相關。訓練生物特徵（例如人臉）模型，意謂這些受到法律保護的特徵（例如膚色或生理性徵）會被編碼納入數據，亦會編碼至（演算）模型內。除非模型開發者澈底解決此項問題，則這些法律保護的生物特徵恐會影響模型效能優劣。

更糟的是，（演算）模型恐會透過「捷徑學習」（Short-Cut Learning），找到數據特徵間的錯誤關聯。例如，訓練過程中，某個生物特徵模型恐會誤將某個接受保護的特徵（例如膚色）與特定結果產生關聯，惟兩者之間並無因果關係，尤其是當訓練數據欠缺足夠反例時，更會發生如此情況。根據（演算）模型使用方式，此類演算法缺陷恐會導致傷害與歧視。在國家安全範疇下，使用有缺陷之人工智慧系統分析美國境外人口將會導致嚴重後果，因為這些人口通常是軍事行動中之有利目標。而這些受到分析之對象，並無美國公民的法律追索權，可修正模型造成的偏差。

雖然此類對於演算法的限制，強調公平與正義面向，卻忽略一項重要的國家安全意涵，即演算法的限制也是重要的效能考量。即便運用具有缺陷之人工智慧模型，不會導致歧視或產生不公平結果，一個在特定情況下（即分析特定族群時）效能明顯不足的（演算）模型亦不可靠。若運用具有缺陷模型之分析員無法察覺其限制，恐會導致分析錯誤，進而影響決策過程，即此舉不僅會影響情報判斷成果，亦會影響據此下達決心的決策高層。再者，若演算法以美國種族與族群類別為基礎，此類（演算）模型恐會無法釐清特定國家人種與不同國家民族間之重要差異，從而使得對其效能與公平性之擔憂更加惡化。
本文作者群協力進行演算法效能兵棋推演，探討該演算法在軍事情報領域，如何對決策構成負面影響。我們透過聯戰專業軍事教育課堂進行是項推演，希望協助未來領導幹部預見人工智慧技術潛在問題，先行預擬應對戰略。
◎推演過程

此次兵棋推演名為深偽事件反應（Deepfake Incident Response），係由IQT實驗室與Luminos.Law法律事務所共同開發，推演中運用名為揭偽者（FakeFinder）的虛構人工智慧工具，藉此運用人工智慧判別影像是否為深偽生成。超過90分鐘的推演時間中，參演人員扮演美國情報單位人工智慧事件反應小組成員。此次推演場景設定為高張力的地緣政治狀況，而一支特定影片的真實性會左右變局，分析員運用揭偽者評估影片真偽。推演主持人引導參演人員進行討論，首先對「事件初期報告」（Initial Incident Report）進行回應，是項報告提出證詞說明揭偽者工具成效不佳，之後再應對一連串推演過程中出現之轉折「情節」（Inject），使狀況更加複雜、事態嚴重性升高。
揭偽者須依照個人專長與專業分工設職，讓參演人員充分發揮專業，預判推演期間所生風險與潛在衝擊。(Source: shutterstock)
推演過程中，人工智慧事件反應小組每位參演人員負責不同任務。其中，有人擔任資料科學家、資深分析員、法律／隱私權關係人、溝通關係人、資安關係人、對外連絡官以及小組副組長等職務，刻意依照個人專長與專業分工設職，讓參演人員充分發揮專業，預判推演期間所生風險類別與潛在衝擊。

儘管這次推演想定全為虛構，但卻是依據先前模擬敵攻擊演習成果進行設計。2021年，IQT實驗室進行模擬敵攻擊演習，而是項演習驗證深偽偵測挑戰賽（Deepfake Detection Challenge）期間生成之數種開源深偽偵測模型。IQT實驗室對挑戰賽中表現最佳的多個（演算）模型進行測試，但相關測試結果仍有數項令人擔憂的限制。例如，運用其中一個模型辨識東亞臉孔影片時，誤判情形近乎是辨識白人臉孔影片的六倍以上—亦即錯將真實影片辨識為深偽影片。
IQT實驗室過去曾與美國情報領域共同進行深偽事件反應推演，但此次推演係首度由美國國防部試行。美國國防大學資訊暨網路空間學院置重點於傳授軍職人員運用科技進行戰略決策，以及倫理在領導統御上扮演之角色。因此，資訊暨網路空間學院邀請IQT實驗室在碩士學程中分享這項推演，並納入人工智慧與軍事倫理教程。
該學院提供聯合部隊官兵、國家安全領導幹部，以及網路領域與資訊環境專業人員相關建議，讓前述人員在國家與全球安全領域發揮帶頭作用、不斷精進。參訓學員通常為軍職、文職或其他國家學官，階級約在中、上校位階或文職薪俸總等級表14至15級且具備發展潛力。因應戰爭型態質變，美國必須在聯戰專業軍事教育上採取嶄新作法（例如透過前述推演），探索人工智慧在軍事倫理中的影響。
◎推演檢討
兩位參演學員分別擔任資深分析員與副組長，推演觀察如次：

帕賈諾─華勒斯（Lisa Pagano-Wallace）上校指出：決策與科技速度並進。個人擔任資深分析員。對我來言，這就像家常便飯；過去20年，個人一直在空軍從事情報工作，因此對於推演職務工作內容還算得心應手。個人亦對運用人工智慧進行預測分析，以及監測徵候與提供預警的想法很感興趣，但亦深知建立堅實可靠的數據集相當曠日廢時，且有賴分析員發揮所長。此次推演經驗，復以我對臉部辨識技術問題之理解（坦白說，我的理解很粗淺，且大部分是從聽『播客』節目而來），讓我對推演使用的揭偽者工具抱持高度懷疑態度。個人亦傾向相信推演想定所設人物，這是因為該人物將自己的影片輸入是項工具進行測試後，聲稱該工具確有缺陷。

首先，身為學員，個人會珍惜任何主動學習機會，所以對於參與此次倫理與人工智慧推演充滿高度熱誠。學期初，資訊暨網路空間學院戰略思維與溝通課程中，學員曾研讀具有開創性的〈論隨機鸚鵡的危險：語言模型夠大嗎？〉（On the Dangers of Stochastic Parrots: Can Language Models Be Too Big?）一文，預先瞭解人工智慧資料模型之危險與潛在缺陷，但尚無機會將文章見解結合情報專業。不過，此次推演將個人學術知識投入實務應用。
初期印象左右個人後續推演觀點—首先，影片真偽評估結果僅有中度至低度可信度；其次，前述看法係導因於評估工具不良，而非情報錯誤。此項觀點使我與資料科學家的立場全然相反，因為個人質疑資料分析工具可信度，並試圖將責任從轄下小組轉移至資料小組。此舉亦讓我肩負兩項重要任務：為分析員爭取時間以驗證揭偽者產出之結果，以及說服副組長，不得輕信影片為真。
2024年12月11日，美國國防部數位與人工智慧長（Chief Digital and Artificial Intelligence）普蘭姆（Radha Plumb）宣布解散利馬工作小組，並在國防部內成立人工智慧快速能力辦公室（AI Rapid Capabilities Office）。(Source: US DoD/Madelyn Keech)

推演想定升高情勢，即中國即將入侵臺灣，對個人形成分秒必爭之壓力，亦增加忽視揭偽者辨識結果所構成之風險。這場典型「時間不足，無法產製完美情報」的轉折，引起激烈辯論，參演人員在情勢升高情況下，聚焦不舉報影片之風險，並討論如何適當界定人為評估的可信度。小組最後還是決定提出這項情報，然結果並不正確，且受到（推演中的）總統高級顧問嚴厲斥責—如此一來，個人更加認同此項教訓，即運用科技快速做出決策，結果恐會令人擔憂、充滿風險。但失敗卻為學習之母，對吧？
此次推演有幾個面向值得個人深入思考：一、瞭解工具開發歷程對情報專業人員至關重要，尤其是情資預測相關能力。二、危機期間，建立關係非常重要；個人認為，由於參演人員來自不同研究組別，對彼此觀點瞭解不足，阻滯我方決策時效。三、個人也有一番新的體悟：無論情報循傳統系統產製或由人工智慧生成，情報評估必須清晰明瞭，情報來源也要充分審查或詳細揭露。當分析員不熟悉所獲數據或所運用的演算法時，情報評估恐會更加複雜。

孟都薩（Hermie Mendoza）中校稱：察覺我們對機器的信任。根據羅傑斯（Everett Rogers）採用曲線（Adoption Curve），個人屬於所謂的「早期大眾」（Early Majority）。如同其他務實的「早期大眾」使用者，當「早期採用者」（Early Adopter）證實新科技的預期效能後，個人才會將是項科技納入個人「數位工具」庫。身為資訊暨網路空間學院學員，個人早期大眾之傾向受到許多教員質疑，尤其中共與俄羅斯「大國競爭」態勢與日俱增。從國家安全角度來看，美國若要取得壓倒性優勢，就必須全面採取「創新者」或「早期採用者」作法來接受人工智慧、量子運算及其他新興技術。因此，當前與未來國家安全領導幹部應鼓勵資訊與通信技術公司跨越早期採用者與早期大眾的鴻溝，將新技術融入政府現行模式。

為讓學員體驗人工智慧帶來之挑戰，同時培養批判性思維，教員主辦此次推演，處置模擬情報形塑之國家安全議題。個人在推演中擔任副組長，負責協調整合跨領域人工智慧事件反應小組全般工作，與組內、組外關係人溝通，並在人工智慧工具故障時調整組織作業流程。表面上，副組長職責相當明確。但推演期間，個人有意擔負另一項責任，就是培養坦誠工作文化，對上級據實以報（Speaking Truth to Power）並勇於創新。就我所見，此種領導統御作法培養小組合作的風氣，進而能迅速追根究柢、調查相互關係、修正（情報）產製過程效能不彰的人工智慧工具，以及修正情報程序與處理過程。如果聚焦究責，勢必分散心力，無法支持上級決策過程。對我而言，重要的是要找到前進方向，提高情報可信度與準確度，同時維繫單位信譽。

整個推演研討過程中，個人發現自己將重點置於倫理、對科技之信任，以及情報單位成為人工智慧「早期採用者」等三項要務間之交集。雖然此次模擬推演成果不佳，但個人認為是個絕佳學習機會，參演單位與整個情報領域都受益無窮。此次推演充分展現，參演單位具備充足的人工智慧系統工具相關知識，同時亦顯現單位信守作業公開透明與即時應處問題之承諾。儘管過程中遭遇問題，組內、外關係人也會施加壓力，但維持透明仍是正確選擇。期待隨著時間推移，作業透明能逐步重拾大家對於人工智慧工具之信任，也會提高未來情報評估的可信度，並儘可能減低人員運用人工智慧產製資料時，下意識忽略人工智慧模組的限制因素。

2018年11月26日，美國維吉尼亞州阿靈頓海軍研究辦公室（Office of Naval Research）的系列講座中，艾倫人工智慧研究院（Allen Institute for Artificial Intelligence）執行長暨美國華盛頓大學（University of Washington）電腦科學教授艾齊歐尼（Oren Etzioni）探討如何學習基本常識—此係人工智慧學界之重大研究挑戰。(Source: USN/John F. Williams)

最令個人擔憂的後果是，偏差資料與人機決策技能發展所帶來之衝擊。人工智慧工具無法結合現況進行分析，因此人類必須評估分析結果的可信度。重複運用同一分析結果，尤其是在訓練數據有限的情況下，可能導致人們在其他互動情境中持續受這些結果誤導，進而增加後續決策風險。此次推演揭示這項問題，強調人類逐漸自然而然地相信機器所生成之結果。正是因為這種對人工智慧工具的信任，恐導致重度依賴人工智慧的組織，於遭遇人工智慧事件時將感到特別棘手。因此，無論組織或個人對於運用技術有任何偏好，運用人工智慧工具時，必須謹記俄羅斯亙古流傳的諺語「即便信得過，也要查證」（Trust but Verify），這仍是重要指導原則。
◎總結
若未充分瞭解演算法效能與可靠度的複雜性，恐對下級單位產生不良影響。測試有助於揭露特定弱點，先行研擬解決方案。例如，運用特定數據集訓練與微調（演算）模型，以避免某些嚴重危害。然而，這些限制因素無法完全修復；重新訓練等技術層面解決方案，無法消除所有限制因素，亦無法杜絕負面衝擊。

依據德西奧（Filippo Santoni de Sio，譯注：荷蘭哲學家，主要研究人工智慧的倫理學與責任問題）與梅卡奇（Giulio Mecacci，譯注：荷蘭人工智慧倫理學與哲學學者，經常與德西奧合作進行研究）所言：「關於人工智慧具有『責任差距』（Responsibility Gap）之想法始現於哲學辯論，用於彰顯人們擔憂『學習自動機』（Learning Automata，譯注：此為一種機器學習之演算法，係依據過去生活經驗採取當前行動）恐難以或無法將不良事件（Untoward Event）的道德罪責，歸咎於特定個人所造成。」而這些（演算）模型與數據助長這種不確定性，並擴大軍事領導幹部的倫理灰色地帶。
評估人工智慧工具效能的要項關乎「對人類」造成之不良後果。人工智慧技術考量無法與構成危害之概念完全切割。若僅將效能不佳視為是必須修補或修復之軟體錯誤，就會輕乎人類影響之複雜程度，並冒著忽視社會、文化及政治連鎖反應之風險。同時，可能造成的危險是，我們無法發現效能不佳的工具，如何造成決策過程中不易察覺的漏洞。

此次深偽事件反應兵棋推演，以數種方式凸顯演算法效能無法只憑技術手段解決，必須採取更全面之作法。舉例而言，人工智慧工具生成結果良窳不一，而正如（演算）模型的測試結果所揭櫫，生成結果可能會因取樣個體類別、等級或人口統計群體而有所不同。然依前文所述，如何讓情報分析員理解前述結果差異，藉此評估工具生成情報之可信度？抑或，倘若某個工具生成錯誤資訊，導致決策錯誤，即使修正是項特定缺陷後，過去的錯誤決策將如何影響未來使用者對該工具之信任？推演過程中，參演人員觀察到技術問題如何更加盤根錯節，引發後續責任歸屬議題。此種思考架構，有助於打破視當前模型為常態、任何偏差都不會演變成重大問題之思維，反而會將（演算）效能視為一種系統性挑戰。
在聯戰專業軍事教育中，學員學習成為戰略領導者之倫理決策。此種作法依賴多元觀點，確保關鍵決策禁得起各種考驗。當國家安全部門更進一步運用人工智慧技術，就能更深入瞭解人工智慧明辨與傳達各種概念的重要性。在課堂上探討前述新興技術之潛在影響，不僅能讓學員練習演運應對作法，亦能透過與同儕進行批判性討論以反思這些方法是否有效。
作者簡介
Andrea Brennen為IQT（In-Q-Tel）實驗室資深副總裁暨副主任。
Gwyneth Sutherlin為美國國防大學資訊暨網路空間學院網路安全學會（University Consortium for Cybersecurity）會長。
Lisa Pagano-Wallace美空軍上校為美國國家情報總監辦公室資深軍種顧問。
Hermie Mendoza美國海岸防衛隊中校為大西洋區域C5I暨安全部門（大西洋區第6處）副處長。
